awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is derived by significantly lowering the production costs of cation-exchange membranes. By replacing expensive membranes with low-cost alternatives, this technology may find application in redox flow batteries used as utility-scale energy storage devices. The reduction of the production costs of redox flow batteries may enable increased adoption of wind and solar energy sources since large-scale energy storage is a bottleneck that currently impedes growth of renewable electricity markets. This technology may also find application in hydrogen fuel cells.  The reduced fuel cell production costs could allow for easier adoption of fuel cell-powered vehicles resulting in the reduction of emissions in the transportation sector.

This I-Corps project develops proton-exchange membranes comprised of perfluorophosphonic acid-zirconium polymers. These membranes are derived from affordable natural materials resulting in the potential for low-cost manufacturing via a new synthetic strategy that employs novel free-radical coupling reactions. Proof-of-concept investigations show that these new membranes demonstrate high proton conductivity in water and may significantly reduce vanadium crossovers for redox flow battery applications. This I-Corps project may help identify potential commercialization pathways for these materials and process innovations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
The Southern Illinois University Carbondale (SIUC) team is comprised of Mr. Matthew Thompson (EL), Prof. Yong Gao (TL), Dr. Rong Jiang (co-TL), and Dr. Deb Barnet (IM). The team has accomplished the followings:

 

(1)   The team attended the training course in the fall of 2021 and graduated from the I-Corps program;

(2)   The team conducted 101 customer-discovery interviews;

(3)   A niche market was identified for us to develop novel membrane-based redox flow batteries;

(4)   Mr. Matthew Thompson graduated with a Ph.D. degree with the support of this I-Corps award;

(5)   Prof. Gao received two NSF research awards (2212545 & 2227265) in 2022 because of the I-Corps training;

(6)   Energao, Inc.?a startup company focusing on commercializing membrane-based batteries was founded by Dr. Jiang

(7)   Energao, Inc. filed two patent applications;

(8)   Enerago, Inc. received an SBIR phase I award from the USDA and NSF, respectively.

This I-Corps award has been enormously helpful to the SIUC team. With the help of this award, Matthew Thompson graduated with a Ph.D. degree in the fall of 2022. He now serves as a laboratory manager in SIUC. To Prof. Gao, this award helped him identify the market needs and focus his research on solving practical challenges faced by society. Based on this I-Corps project, Dr. Gao was able to attract two more NSF projects, and he himself was promoted to full professorship in 2023. Other team members, like Dr. Jiang created Energao, Inc. and she is conducting active SBIR research.
